[SEP] During the past two centuries, however, some of the sailors have turned away from fishing and instead, taken to the cargo trade between Portugal and North Africa. column1: Goa Lawah Considered one of Bali’s oddities, the Bat Cave and its temple are hemmed in by souvenir stalls, hawkers, sash dispensers, donation collectors, ticket sellers, and, for most of the day, parked tour buses. [SEP] Once past this obstacle course, you’ll see the cave mouth and a seething mass of leathery bats clinging to the rock face, here and there dropping off, circling and then
column3: in to land again. [SEP] They can’t all find a place in the cave, so some hang outside in broad daylight. [SEP] If you are staying anywhere near, perhaps at Candi Dasa, you might time a visit here for dusk. [SEP] That’s when the bat colony pours out of the cave like a liquid black stream and wheels away into the distance to feed on the myriad insects of the tropical night. [SEP] On the foreshore near the Bat Cave, a few people scratch a living by harvesting salt. [SEP] Seawater is first concentrated by solar evaporation in shallow pans and then transferred to the hollowed-out halves of palm tree trunks to crystallize.

[SEP] The whole Yucatán peninsula witnessed the flowering of classic Mayan civilization and a society of great sophistication; with its magnificent pyramids, temples, and palaces decorated with wall paintings and carved low-reliefs, a written language of hieroglyphics, and complicated medical procedures to heal the injured or the sick. [SEP] Mayan astronomers tracked the movements of the heavenly bodies, predicting eclipses and marking the times for the planting of the new corn. [SEP] In fact, corn came to symbolize life for the Maya — in their myths of creation, mankind was formed from lumps of maize dough. [SEP] Elaborate rituals grew up around the preparation of the milpas (cornfields) and the planting and harvesting of the crop whose success depended on the
column3: of the annual rains. [SEP] These rituals were undertaken by a small number of initiates who controlled the knowledge of the Maya. [SEP] Because the region has no surface rivers, rain was a precious resource and the Maya saw any stock of water, such as the limestone water holes or cenotes, as holy places. [SEP] The rain god Chaac was a very important deity, whose image can be seen at every Mayan site. [SEP] But there was a dark side to this sophisticated society. [SEP] The Maya viewed their gods not as benevolent guides but as changeable spirits in need of constant appeasement. [SEP] To incur the wrath of the gods would result in drought, a loss of crops, and certain starvation. [SEP] To keep the gods happy, the people offered sacrifices at their great pyramid temples. [SEP] In early 1976 the widely admired prime minister, Zhou Enlai, died. [SEP] Eight months later, in September, death came to Chairman Mao himself. [SEP] Mao’s widow, the one-time film actress Jiangqing, and her close associates (the so-called Gang of Four) were arrested, tried, and imprisoned for encouraging the excesses of the Cultural Revolution. [SEP] Thousands who had suffered during the fervid 1960s and 1970s, including the forceful pragmatist Deng Xiaoping, were rehabilitated. [SEP] At the same time as Mao Zedong’s portraits and slogans were being removed from billboards and schoolrooms, a new flexibility was
column3: to the fore. [SEP] Top priority was now assigned to the modernization of China’s underdeveloped economy. [SEP] This opened the way for major scientific and commercial exchanges with the West. [SEP] And foreign tourists soon began flooding into the country to see the splendors that had been inaccessible for so long. [SEP] In 1992 “Supreme Leader” Deng Xiaoping set into motion a rapid Westernization of China’s economy. [SEP] Deng’s death and Hong Kong’s return to Chinese sovereignty in 1997 together marked another new era in the creation of a New China, this time as an economic superpower designed to rival the US and Europe in the 21st century.
